choices.text:
the disappointing performance of the Thai government in responding to the needs of the elderly. Aging is inevitable and will be normal demographic process for the shorter term, and significant demographic change in the longer term, therefore, Thai government should develop an integrated care policy for those living outside the institutional care setting. I expect the government would share a vision for elderly population, provides legislation and regulation, improve support of caregivers and tackle the stigma of caring for the elderly.

How should Thailand address end-of-life needs?

In Thailand, it’s an unwritten rule that all Thai citizens are treated equally when they go to hospital. Unfortunately, this is not true when they are approaching end-of-life. The point is no one knows when they will die. End-of-life is very personal situation and the law can treat health professionals differently. Each case is different, so there needs to be more flexibility and focus on helping people make more informed decisions. The law isn’t always the best tool for articulating individual rights and should be complemented by patient- and family-centered c
